message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Behavioral Game Theory
Paper Abstract: People deviate from the predictions of game theory in two systematic ways. They are not purely self-interested (they care about fairness and try to cooperate with others), and they do not always consider what other players will do before making choices. However, with experience, these deviations sometimes disappear. People learn when they can afford to be unfair and what others will do; their behavior often converges to a game-theoretic equilibrium. A behavioral game theory that explains the initial deviations (and their disappearance) could be useful, especially if the learning process is modeled carefully and better data are gathered.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Behavioral Economics: Search Results

I've found comprehensive information about behavioral economics. Here are the key findings:

### Definition and Overview

Behavioral economics is the study of the psychological factors (cognitive, behavioral, affective, social) involved in the decisions of individuals or institutions, and how these decisions deviate from those implied by traditional economic theory.(no content)It is primarily concerned with the bounds of rationality of economic agents.

### Interdisciplinary Approach

Behavioral models typically integrate insights from psychology, neuroscience and microeconomic theory.

### Historical Development

Behavioral economics began as a distinct field of study in the 1970s and 1980s, but can be traced back to 18th-century economists, such as Adam Smith, who deliberated how the economic behavior of individuals could be influenced by their desires.(no content)With Amos Tversky and others, Daniel Kahneman established a cognitive basis for common human errors that arise from heuristics and biases, and developed prospect theory.

### Key Insights

Behavioral economists have accumulated extensive findings indicating, contrary to standard economic assumptions, that people do not act rationally, that they are not perfectly self-interested, and that they hold inconsistent preferences.

### Applications

Behavioral economics and public policy is a field that investigates how the discipline of behavioral economics can be used to enhance the formation, implementation and evaluation of public policy, using behavioral insights to explore how to make policies more effective, efficient and humane by considering real-world human behavior and decision-making.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of Learning Theory:

## Definition and Overview

Learning theory attempts to describe how students receive, process, and retain knowledge during learning.(no content)In psychology and education, learning theories are attempts to describe how people and animals learn, thereby helping us understand the inherently complex process of learning.

## Key Factors

Cognitive, emotional, and environmental influences, as well as prior experience, all play a part in how understanding, or a worldview, is acquired or changed and knowledge and skills retained.

## Major Learning Theories

**Behavioral Learning:** In behavior analysis, learning is the acquisition of a new behavior through conditioning and social learning.(no content)The three main types of conditioning and learning: Classical conditioning, where the behavior becomes a reflex response to an antecedent stimulus. Operant conditioning, where antecedent stimuli results from the consequences that follow the behavior through a reward (reinforcement) or a punishment. Social learning theory, where an observation of behavior is followed by modeling.

**Social Learning Theory:** Social learning theory is a psychological theory of social behavior that explains how people acquire new behaviors, attitudes, and emotional reactions through observing and imitating others.

**Constructionism:** Constructionism advocates student-centered, discovery learning where students use what they already know to acquire more knowledge. Students learn through participation in project-based learning where they make connections between different ideas and areas of knowledge facilitated by the teacher through coaching rather than using lectures or step-by-step guidance.

## Computational Learning Theory

In computer science, computational learning theory (or just learning theory) is a subfield of artificial intelligence devoted to studying the design and analysis of machine learning algorithms.

Links: [{"title":"Nash equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nash_equilibrium"},{"title":"Manipulated Nash equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manipulated_Nash_equilibrium"},{"title":"Strong Nash equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strong_Nash_equilibrium"},{"title":"Talk:Nash equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Nash_equilibrium"},{"title":"Epsilon-equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epsilon-equilibrium"},{"title":"Coalition-proof Nash equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coalition-proof_Nash_equilibrium"},{"title":"Correlated equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Correlated_equilibrium"},{"title":"Nash equilibrium computation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nash_equilibrium_computation"},{"title":"Mertens-stable equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mertens-stable_equilibrium"},{"title":"Markov perfect equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_perfect_equilibrium"}]

Here's what I found about Nash Equilibrium:

## Overview

Game theorists use Nash equilibrium to analyze the outcome of the strategic interaction of several decision makers.(no content)Nash equilibrium is achieved when no player can improve their outcome by changing their decision, assuming the other players' choices remain unchanged.

## Core Concept

One cannot predict the choices of multiple decision makers if one analyzes those decisions in isolation. Instead, one must ask what each player would do taking into account what the player expects the others to do.(no content)In a strategic interaction, the outcome for each decision-maker depends on the decisions of the others as well as their own.

## Historical Development

Nash equilibrium is named after American mathematician John Forbes Nash Jr. However, the idea of Nash equilibrium dates back to the time of Cournot, who in 1838 applied it to his model of competition in an oligopoly.(no content)John Nash showed that there is a Nash equilibrium, possibly in mixed strategies, for every finite game.

## Applications

The concept has been used to analyze hostile situations such as wars and arms races, how conflict may be mitigated by repeated interaction, how people with different preferences can cooperate, and to study the adoption of technical standards and the occurrence of bank runs and currency crises.

Links: [{"title":"Game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_theory"},{"title":"List of games in game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_games_in_game_theory"},{"title":"Game Theory (band) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_Theory_(band)"},{"title":"Combinatorial game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Combinatorial_game_theory"},{"title":"Behavioral game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_game_theory"},{"title":"Mean-field game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean-field_game_theory"},{"title":"Battle of the sexes (game theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_the_sexes_(game_theory)"},{"title":"Non-cooperative game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-cooperative_game_theory"},{"title":"Two-level game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two-level_game_theory"},{"title":"Algorithmic game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorithmic_game_theory"}]

Here are the search results for "Game Theory":

## Overview

Game theory is the study of mathematical models of strategic interactions.(no content)It has applications in many fields of social science, and is used extensively in economics, logic, systems science and computer science.

## Historical Development

Modern game theory began with the idea of mixed-strategy equilibria in two-person zero-sum games and its proof by John von Neumann.(no content)Initially, game theory addressed two-person zero-sum games, in which a participant's gains or losses are exactly balanced by the losses and gains of the other participant.(no content)In the 1950s, it was extended to the study of non zero-sum games, and was eventually applied to a wide range of behavioral relations.

## Key Concepts

Nash's most famous contribution to game theory is the concept of the Nash equilibrium, which is a solution concept for non-cooperative games, published in 1951. A Nash equilibrium is a set of strategies, one for each player, such that no player can improve their payoff by unilaterally changing their strategy.

## Types of Game Theory

The field includes several specialized branches:

- **Behavioral Game Theory**: Behavioral game theory seeks to examine how people's strategic decision-making behavior is shaped by social preferences, social utility and other psychological factors.

- **Combinatorial Game Theory**: Combinatorial game theory is a branch of mathematics and theoretical computer science that typically studies sequential games with perfect information.

- **Mean-field Game Theory**: Mean-field game theory is the study of strategic decision making by small interacting agents in very large populations.

## Recognition

Fifteen game theorists have won the Nobel Prize in economics as of 2020.

Links: [{"title":"Game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_theory"},{"title":"List of games in game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_games_in_game_theory"},{"title":"Game Theory (band) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_Theory_(band)"},{"title":"Combinatorial game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Combinatorial_game_theory"},{"title":"Behavioral game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_game_theory"},{"title":"Mean-field game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean-field_game_theory"},{"title":"Battle of the sexes (game theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_the_sexes_(game_theory)"},{"title":"Non-cooperative game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-cooperative_game_theory"},{"title":"Two-level game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two-level_game_theory"},{"title":"Algorithmic game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorithmic_game_theory"}]

Here are the search results for "Game Theory":

## Overview

Game theory is the study of mathematical models of strategic interactions.(no content)It has applications in many fields of social science, and is used extensively in economics, logic, systems science and computer science.

## Historical Development

Modern game theory began with the idea of mixed-strategy equilibria in two-person zero-sum games and its proof by John von Neumann.(no content)Initially, game theory addressed two-person zero-sum games, in which a participant's gains or losses are exactly balanced by the losses and gains of the other participant.(no content)In the 1950s, it was extended to the study of non zero-sum games, and was eventually applied to a wide range of behavioral relations.

## Key Concepts

Nash's most famous contribution to game theory is the concept of the Nash equilibrium, which is a solution concept for non-cooperative games, published in 1951. A Nash equilibrium is a set of strategies, one for each player, such that no player can improve their payoff by unilaterally changing their strategy.

## Types of Game Theory

The field includes several specialized branches:

- **Behavioral Game Theory**: Behavioral game theory seeks to examine how people's strategic decision-making behavior is shaped by social preferences, social utility and other psychological factors.

- **Combinatorial Game Theory**: Combinatorial game theory is a branch of mathematics and theoretical computer science that typically studies sequential games with perfect information.

- **Mean-field Game Theory**: Mean-field game theory is the study of strategic decision making by small interacting agents in very large populations.

## Recognition

Fifteen game theorists have won the Nobel Prize in economics as of 2020.

Links: [{"title":"Equity (economics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equity_(economics)"},{"title":"Free Market Fairness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_Market_Fairness"},{"title":"Intergenerational equity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intergenerational_equity"},{"title":"Social preferences - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_preferences"},{"title":"Wealth maximization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wealth_maximization"},{"title":"Economic fairness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_fairness"},{"title":"Erik S. Reinert - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erik_Reinert"},{"title":"2025 Bermudian general election - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Bermudian_general_election"},{"title":"Progressive capitalism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Progressive_capitalism"},{"title":"Equity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equity"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of Fairness Economics:

## Definition and Core Concept

Economic equity is the construct, concept or idea of fairness in economics and justice in the distribution of wealth, resources, and taxation within a society.(no content)Equity in economics refers to a condition of fairness where the economic processes and their outcomes do not unduly favor or disadvantage any particular group or individual, attempting to balance economic disparities among different societal segments to promote a more inclusive and just society.

## Key Areas of Focus

Equity is closely tied to taxation policies, welfare economics, and the discussions of public finance, influencing how resources are allocated among different segments of the population.(no content)Equity is a central issue in public sector economics and in public policy, at the heart of almost all economics policy debates, which underscores the integral role that equity plays in shaping public decisions that impact overall societal welfare.

## Measurement and Frameworks

Equity looks at the distribution of capital, goods, and access to services throughout an economy and is often measured using tools such as the Gini index.(no content)Equity axioms are theoretical constructs that provide frameworks for understanding and implementing fairness in economic policies, divided in two broad categories: procedural and consequentialist.

## Challenges

Defining equity presents inherent challenges due to its subjective nature, which depends heavily on societal values and individual perceptions of what is considered fair, with economists often struggling to establish a universally accepted definition of distributional equity because it involves making interpersonal comparisons of utility.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Cooperation"

Links: [{"title":"Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperation"},{"title":"Shanghai Cooperation Organisation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation"},{"title":"The Evolution of Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Evolution_of_Cooperation"},{"title":"Japan International Cooperation Agency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan_International_Cooperation_Agency"},{"title":"Cooperation (evolution) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperation_(evolution)"},{"title":"Mekong–Ganga Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mekong–Ganga_Cooperation"},{"title":"Permanent Structured Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Permanent_Structured_Cooperation"},{"title":"Organisation of Islamic Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation"},{"title":"Cooperative - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative"},{"title":"Economy of the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_the_Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation"}]

Here are the search results for "Cooperation":

## Definition and Basic Concept

Cooperation takes place when a group of organisms works or acts together for a collective benefit to the group as opposed to working in competition for selfish individual benefit. In evolutionary terms, cooperation is the process where groups of organisms work or act together for common or mutual benefits.

## Cooperation in Human Societies

Every human achievement is actually reliant on the cooperation efforts that have been created by others, from the cursory to the truly magnificent, whether its a mundane achievement or the greatest achievements.(no content)Humans are biologically geared to ensuring survival by social instincts like much of the food early human beings ate were hunted or gathered, these are aspects of cooperation that alone cannot be done.

## Cooperation in Nature

Many organisms other than apes, such as fish, birds, and insects exhibit cooperative behavior: teaching, helping, and self-sacrifice, and can coordinate to solve problems.(no content)One specific form of cooperation in animals is kin selection, which involves animals promoting the reproductive success of their kin, thereby promoting their own fitness.

## Organizational Forms

A practical form of cooperation in modern societies is the cooperative. A cooperative is "an autonomous association of persons united voluntarily to meet their common economic, social and cultural needs and aspirations through a jointly owned and democratically-controlled enterprise".(no content)Research published by the Worldwatch Institute found that in 2012 approximately one billion people in 96 countries had become members of at least one cooperative.

The search results also include information about various international cooperation organizations, such as the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation, the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation, and other multilateral frameworks focused on regional or sectoral cooperation.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name, relation, entity_type, wikipedia_url, relevance.

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
